newsitem.title: INDIA: Hindu opposition party begins march across India.
newsitem.headline: Hindu opposition party begins march across India.

text.p: India's main opposition party, the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), said on Sunday it opposed a proposal for a working group from India and Pakistan to discuss the future of divided Kashmir.

"There is no need to form such a group. Our party is opposed to the formation of such a group," Atal Behari Vajpayee, BJP leader and former prime minister, said as he waved off a cross-country march by party president Lal Krishna Advani.

Last week, Indian Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral and Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif agreed to set up working groups to discuss issues, including Kashmir, dividing the two long-standing rivals.
The two prime ministers met in the Maldivian capital of Male on the sidelines of a South Asian summit there.
Vajpayee told dozens of saffron-clad party workers that if there is any discussion at all on Kashmir, it should be to regain control of the Pakistan-occupied part of the Himalayan region.

India and Pakistan have fought two wars over Kashmir since independence from Britain in 1947. India controls two-thirds of Kashmir -- and is fighting a separatist revolt there -- and Pakistan the rest.
Advani's "Swarna Jayathi Rath Yatra", or golden jubilee march, covers 15,000 km (9,375 miles) across 15 states and one union territory and is to mark 50 years of independence from Britain.

Analysts said the 55-day trip, ending on July 1 in New Delhi, is a thinly veiled start to the party's campaign to woo The largest single group in parliament's lower house, the BJP is racing to position itself for mid-term elections it is convinced will be called later this year.
"Naturally the impact of it (the march) will go to build the image of the party," BJP vice-president Jana Krishnamurthy told Reuters in New Delhi.
Opinion polls favour the BJP, which now holds 162 of the 545 seats in the Lok Sabha lower house, in the event of an election.
BJP leaders say they are convinced Gujral's centre-left coalition is short-lived and will tumble by the year end.
Thousands of the BJP's saffron and green flags dotted the route out of the commercial capital as Advani and his convoy of cars, buses, taxis and two-wheelers took off on their journey.
Advani, seated on a gaily decorated chariot mounted on a truck, told the crowd that India must be rid of all corruption.

"I feel very bad when I look at what 50 years of independence has done to India. We are still not free or self-reliant. If you vote the BJP to power at the centre, I promise a clean government which will make India self-reliant and free."
India's political arena has been mired in corruption scandals that has plagued the the former ruling Congress party and now constituents of Gujral's coalition government.
